snippet: The case of David Shea, who is facing eviction from his affordable housing development, is another battle in the fight over whether New Yorkers should be permitted to rent out their spare space.
abstract: The Appraisal column examines case of David Shea, who is facing eviction from his affordable housing co-op development in Midtown Manhattan after posting notice on Internet that he was willing to rent out his large enclosed terrace; his case is yet another battle in fight over whether New Yorkers should be permitted to sublet apartment space, which state argues costs millions in lost hotel occupancy taxes.
lead_paragraph: The case of David Shea, who is facing eviction from his affordable housing development, is another battle in the fight over whether New Yorkers should be permitted to rent out their spare space.

headline.main: After Renting Out a Terrace, He Received an Eviction Notice
headline.print_headline: After Renting Out a Terrace, He Received an Eviction Notice
